frameDefinitions: An Agent attempts to achieve a Goal.
An Agent or Entity becomes sufficient enough to meet a Standard.

This frame consists of words that indicate that an Agent or a Cause affects the position of an Item on some scale (the Attribute) to change it from an initial value (Value_1) to an end value (Value_2).
In this frame a Patient, which is  an organic substance, undergoes the natural process of decaying from an Initial_state to a Result.
This frame contains verbs that describe emotional experiences and participate in the locative alternation, as in the following examples: '' ' I was boiling with anger.'
This frame contains words describing physical experiences that can affect virtually any part of the body.
frameExamples: This paper does not <t>meet</t> the requirements for graduation.
The company is <t>raising</t> the final dividend from 4.34p to 4.57p, to boost the total by 5.3 percent to 6.36p.
The leaves <t>rotted</t> into a mass of slime.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Agent</fen> makes an attempt to achieve a <fen>Goal</fen>.
The <fen>Goal</fen> is what the <fen>Agent</fen> attempts to achieve.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the attempt occurs.
The place where an attempt is made.
The intentional <fen>Agent</fen> acts to meet to a <fen>Standard</fen>.
The non-intentional <fen>Entity</fen> becomes sufficient enough to meet a <fen>Standard</fen>.
An act or occurence that changes circumstances sufficiently so as to meet a <fen>Standard</fen>.
A condition or requirement that the <fen>Agent</fen>, <fen>Entity</fen>, or <fen>Event</fen> attempt to meet.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen>, <fen>Entity</fen>, or <fen>Event</fen> becomes sufficient in regards to the <fen>Standard</fen>.
The person who causes an entity (Item) to change its positon on a scale with respect to some property (Variable).
The scale along which the <fen>Item</fen> ranges in value.
The entity whose position along a scale is being changed.
The force that causes the change.
When the event occurs.
The location where the <fen>Agent</fen> changes the value of an <fen>Attribute</fen>.
The <fen>Patient</fen> is the entity that undergoes a change.
The <fen>Time</fen> indicates when the rotting occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the rotting occurs.
The Experiencer is the individual that experiences the <fen>Emotion</fen>.

The Emotion experienced (usually restricted to words such as <ment>anger, fury, rage, passion</ment>) can occur as the External Argument or in a PP Complement. Alternatively, there may be no expression of Emotion separate from the target verb:
The words in this frame can occur with an overtly expressed Seat of the Emotion. This frame element occurs as a PP Complement:

The Experiencer is the being who has a physical experience on some part of his  or her body, or internally. Often information about this frame element is incorporated as a possessive determiner into the constituent expressing the Body Part, in which case it is not tagged separately (from Body Part), as shown below: My legs <t>hurt</t>! Sometimes, however, this frame element is expressed as an External Argument in its own right:  <fex name='Experiencer'>I</fex> <t>hurt</t> all over! Here, the phrase <ment>all over</ment> can be considered a kind of generalized Body Part expression, and the pronoun <ment>I</ment> expresses the Experiencer independently. With nouns and adjectives in this frame, the separate expression of the Experiencer is more common: <fex name='Experiencer'>I</fex> have a <t>pain</t> in my leg.

This role is the location on the body where the physical experience takes place, typically expressed as External Argument, often as PP complement: <fex name='Body_part'>My legs</fex> are a little <t>sore</t>. I'm a little <t>sore</t> <fex name='Body_part'>in my legs</fex>.
listRoleExamples: <fex>On the bridge</fex> he attempted to put the wig on.
<fex>The rain</fex> increased the river's flow rate to an astonishing million gallons per second.
As a result, they raised prices <fex>in Peoria</fex>.
<fex>The leaves</fex> rotted into a mass of slime.
<fex>Before he could get to the specimen</fex> , its entrails had decomposed so badly that they had to be thrown away.
Any traces of uneaten food will decompose <fex>in your tank</fex> and foul the water.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: The Less Deceived and Amis with Lucky Jim
